column2: James Monroe Elementary School\r1819 North Lake St. • Madera
column4: Principal\rleonardperez@maderausd.org\rhttps://www.madera.k12.ca.us/monroe\r\r-------2018-19 School Accountability Report Card\r-\rPublished During the 2019-20 School Year\r\rPrincipal’s Message\rOn behalf of the entire James Monroe staff
column5: it is with great pleasure that I welcome you to James\rMonroe Elementary School. James Monroe is located at the Northeast edge of the city limits of\rMadera. We have an enrollment of 681 students in preschool through sixth-grade school. James\rMonroe is an award-winning school and has achieved California Distinguished School Status. James\r--------Monroe is a two-time California School Board Association Golden Bell Winner (1997 and 2001).\rMadera Unified School District\r1902 Howard Rd.The teachers at James Monroe Elementary School work together as grade level teams collaborating\rMadera
column6: CA 93637-5123on student learning. They are dedicated to teaching students and make sure they are learning so\r559.675.4500that they can achieve grade level proficiency. We want to offer each child an equal opportunity to\rwww.madera.k12.ca.usgain a quality education and provide the students the basic foundation to achieve academically and\r\rbecome life-long learners and productive citizens in their community.\rDistrict Governing Board\r\rRuben MendozaBoard President\rArea 3Mission Statement\rrubenmendoza@maderausd.orgOur mission is to teach students and make sure they are learning so that they can achieve grade\r\rlevel proficiency or above. We want to offer each child an equal opportunity to gain a quality\rBrent FernandesBoard Clerk\reducation and provide them the basic foundation to achieve academically and become lifelong\rArea 7\rlearners and productive citizens in their community. We
column7: along with the school board believe that\rbrentfernandes@maderausd.org\rthe futures of children are driven by their aspirations
column8: not bound by their circumstances.\rRay G. SeibertArea 1\rrayseibert@maderausd.orgSchool Vision Statement\r\rIn order for us to achieve our mission we must become facilitators of excellent first instruction\rEd McIntyreArea 2focusing on Common Core State Standards. We must become adaptive teachers who are flexible\redmcintyre@maderausd.org\rand willing to change and take on new challenges and opportunities. We must become a culture of\r\rcollaboration in with the parents
column10: and administrators work together for the good of the\rJoetta FleakArea 4\rstudents.\rjoettafleak@maderausd.org\r\rLucy SalazarArea 5School Values\rlucysalazar@maderausd.orgWe have to be examples of superior behavior and instill excellent values in our students by\r\rexample. We will post our expectation values. We must become a professional working community\rJ. Gordon KennedyArea 6\rwho can respect others and their opinions and appreciate diversity. We must focus on learning

SchwartzDeputy\rSuperintendentJamesMonroeElementaryisoneof26elementary/middle/comprehensive/alternativehigh\rSheryl SisilAssistant Superintendent ofschools in Madera Unified School District. column12: 681 K-6th grade students were\rEducational Servicesenrolled at the school
column13: with classes arranged on a traditional calendar.\rLinda MonrealArea Assistant\rSuperintendent Blue Pyramid\rSpecial Education Program: Monroe serves students with special needs in grades K-6 both through\rJesse CarrascoArea Assistant\ran RSP and SDC model. Our RSP teacher supports students in the general education classrooms as\rSuperintendent Purple Pyramid\rwell as pulls them into small groups to provide skill-based remediation. Our SDC teacher serves\rOracio RodriguezArea Assistant\rstudents in grades 4-6 whose IEP determined that the student needed special education service for\rSuperintendent Red Pyramid\rmore than half of their day. These students are mainstreamed with their peers for lunch
